I want my neighbor to have more than just a torn coat, but not because of personal kindness. It should come from the overall progress in society. The idea is simple, but it took a long time to understand, held back by idealism and sentimentality. Still, it doesn’t take much intelligence to see it…

“Sorry, I don’t have much intelligence myself,” Razumihin interrupted sharply. “Let’s drop this. I started this talk for a reason, but I’m tired of all this meaningless chatter. It’s always the same boring stuff that makes me cringe when others talk like that. You probably want to show off what you know, and I understand that. I just wanted to see what kind of person you are. Many dishonest people have taken the progressive cause and twisted it for their own gain, ruining it for everyone. That’s enough!”

“Excuse me, sir,” Luzhin said, offended and trying to sound important. “Are you implying that I…”

“Oh, come on… how could I? That’s enough,” Razumihin said, turning back to Zossimov to continue their earlier conversation.

Pyotr Petrovitch was smart enough to accept the rejection. He decided to leave in a minute or two. 

“I hope we can be friends,” he said to Raskolnikov, “once you recover and considering the situation…”

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Razumihin expresses his frustration with superficial discussions and the distortion of progressive ideals by unscrupulous individuals.
